page.title: 01LYNEAL TO LOPPINGTON
page.content: This is a quiet farming area with no centres of population. It consists of scattered farms and farm cottages. Most of the farms are mixed but with an emphasis on arable and dairying. Many of the farms are prosperous with substantial dwellings, though the recent E.E.C. dairy quota is having an effect with several od the smaller farmers looking for ways of extra income. One 200 acre farm has recently been sold to a national sand and gravel cpmpany with a view to future extraction (Lyneal Wood 456318). The (now) tenant farmer is conservation consious and has done much to develop spinneys and 'ecological corners'. Income is supplemented here by shoots. Loppington House (475302) was previously a private school for severly disabled children but has recently been aquired as an
